description: From Middle English agayn, from Old English onġēan (“against, again”). Cognate with Old Frisian ajēn (whence North Frisian ijen (“against”)), Danish igen (“again”), Swedish igen (“again”), and Norwegian Bokmål igjen (“again”).

examples: He tangled in tree-tops again and again / And barely missed hitting a tri-motored plane.

entries.meaning: Over and above a factor of one. [from 16thc.]
examples: Cirri l-lxxx, 15, about 12mm. long; first two joints short, about twice as broad as long; third about one-third again [=one and one-third times] as long as broad; fourth and fifth the longest, about half again [=one and a half times] as long as broad; […].

definitionGroups.group: Used metalinguistically, with the repetition being in the discussion, or in the linguistic or pragmatic context of the discussion, rather than in the subject of discussion. [from 16thc.]

entries.meaning: Tell me again, say again; used in asking a question to which one may have already received an answer that one cannot remember.
I ask again, I say again; used in repeating a question or statement.
examples: Again, I'm not criticizing, I just want to understand.

entries.meaning: Here too, here also, in this case as well; used in applying a previously made point to a new instance; sometimes preceded by "here".
examples: Approach B is better than approach A in many respects, but again, there are difficulties in implementing it.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Back in the reverse direction, or to an original starting point. [10th–18thc.]
Back (to a former place or state). [from 11thc.]
examples: We need to bring the old customs to life again.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In return, as a reciprocal action; back. [13th–19thc.]

examples: Again, it is of great consequence to avoid, etc.
And here begynneth the treson of Kynge Marke that he ordayned agayne Sir Trystram.
